docs.title: Index Page
docs.text: This site contains the project documentation for the Python Project Medium Original source: https://github.com/johschmidt42/python-project-johannes

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
The documentation follows the best practice for project documentation as described by Daniele Procida in the Diátaxis documentation framework and consists of four separate parts:

  1. Tutorials
  2. How-To Guides
  3. Reference
  4. Explanation

docs.title: Explanation
docs.text:
This part of the project documentation focuses on an understanding-oriented approach. You'll get a chance to read about the background of the project, as well as reasoning about how it was implemented.

Note: Consider the following points:

  • Give context and background on your library
  • Explain why you created it
  • Provide multiple examples and approaches of how to work with it
  • Help the reader make connections
  • Avoid writing instructions or technical descriptions here

docs.title: How-To-Guides
docs.text: This part of the project documentation focuses on a problem-oriented approach. You'll tackle common tasks that you might have, with the help of the code provided in this project.

docs.title: How To Find Information About Your Favorite Pokémon?
Reference
docs.text: This part of the project documentation focuses on an information-oriented approach. Use it as a reference for the technical implementation of the project code.

docs.title: example_app.service
docs.text: Provides several sample functions. The module contains the following functions: - foo(a, b) - Returns the sum of two numbers (int). - `bar(a)' - Returns a hello message with the input string.

docs.title: bar(name='Frank Herbert')
docs.text:
Says 'Hello' with input. Args: name: input string Returns: A 'Hello' message.

Source code in src/example_app/service.py 
def bar(name: str = "Frank Herbert") -> str:
    """
    Says 'Hello' with input.
    Args:
        name: input string
    Returns:
        A 'Hello' message.
    """
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

docs.title: foo(a, b)
docs.text:
This is a description what the function does. Examples: >>> foo(a=1, b=2) 3 >>> foo(a=4, b=15) 19 Args: a: This is the first summand b: This is the second summand Returns: The summation of a and b.

Source code in src/example_app/service.py 
def foo(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    """
    This is a description what the function does.
    Examples:
        >>> foo(a=1, b=2)
        3
        >>> foo(a=4, b=15)
        19
    Args:
        a: This is the first summand
        b: This is the second summand
    Returns:
        The summation of a and b.
    """
    return a + b

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.text:
This part of the project documentation focuses on a learning-oriented approach. You'll learn how to get started with the code in this project.

Note: Consider the following points:

  • Help newcomers with getting started
  • Teach readers about your library by making them write code
  • Inspire confidence through examples that work for everyone, repeatably
  • Give readers an immediate sense of achievement
  • Show concrete examples, no abstractions
  • Provide the minimum necessary explanation
  • Avoid any distractions
